docs.lead_paragraph: Operating on the brain is usually seen as a last resort when drugs fail, but a new study suggests that having surgery sooner may prevent irreversible damage.

headline.main: Surgery for Epilepsy Gains Urgency in Trial
headline.print_headline: Surgery for Epilepsy Gains Urgency in Trial

docs.abstract: Dr Jerome Engel Jr study in The Journal of the American Medical Association suggests that epilepsy patients should undergo surgery as soon as possible after the failure of anti-epilepsy drugs, rather than pursuing continued medical care.
docs.snippet: Operating on the brain is usually seen as a last resort when drugs fail, but a new study suggests that having surgery sooner may prevent irreversible damage.

keywords.value: Journal of the American Medical Assn
keywords.name: organizations

docs.lead_paragraph: At least once a week, someone, usually a woman over 50, asks me about vitamin D. Perhaps a routine checkup has revealed a deficiency, prompting the doctor to recommend an over-the-counter supplement or, in severe cases, large prescription doses to correct the problem. Often, though, the concern is bone health. Without vitamin D, the body cannot properly absorb calcium, and bones become fragile. At the annual meeting of the American Academy of Orthopaedic Surgeons last month, researchers reported that among 889 adult patients treated for a fracture at a Missouri trauma center, blood levels of vitamin D were ''insufficient'' in 78 percent and ''frankly deficient'' in 39 percent. The study group excluded those with known risk factors for vitamin D deficiency.

headline.main: Personal Health: Reasons That Vitamin D May Matter

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column elaborates on the importance and limitations of vitamin D, which has a well-established role in maintaining bone health and for which some researchers have claimed a wider range of health benefits. Drawing (M)1

docs.lead_paragraph: Talk about sleepless nights. Patients taking prescription sleep aids on a regular basis were nearly five times as likely as non-users to die over a period of two and a half years, according to a recent study. Even those prescribed fewer than 20 pills a year were at risk, the researchers found; heavy users also were more likely to develop cancer.

headline.main: The Consumer: Pills' Risks Complicate Long Wait For Sleep

headline.main: Reasons That Vitamin D May Matter
headline.print_headline: Personal Health: Reasons That Vitamin D May Matter

docs.abstract: Though there are still no large trials to prove or disprove the full worth of vitamin D, studies have linked low levels of it to risks of heart disease, high blood pressure and other diseases.
docs.snippet: Though there are still no large trials to prove or disprove the full worth of vitamin D, studies have linked low levels of it to risks of heart disease, high blood pressure and other diseases.

docs.lead_paragraph: When 18 students started twitching, parents suspected the environment. The answer turned out to be much more complex.

headline.seo: The Mystery of 18 Twitching Teenagers in Le Roy
headline.main: What Happened to the Girls in Le Roy
headline.print_headline: What Happened to the Girls in Le Roy

docs.abstract: Mysterious ailment afflicting 18 students in Le Roy, NY, leads parents to suspect the environment was responsible for children's odd symptoms, like uncontrollable twitching and muscle spasms; repeated tests of both the environment and children result in something far more complex; illness is a combination of conversion disorder, in which stress is subconsciously converted into physical symptoms, and mass psychogenic illness, both of which are poorly understood.
docs.snippet: When 18 students started twitching, parents suspected the environment. The answer turned out to be much more complex.

docs.lead_paragraph: You’re the surrogate charged with making decisions for an incapacitated loved one in the intensive care unit of a California hospital. You’ve also agreed to be part of a study on how such decision-makers interpret information about how patients will fare.

headline.main: Weighing the Chances at Life’s End

docs.abstract: As the prognosis grows more bleak, a study finds, family members begin to misinterpret what doctors are trying to tell them.
docs.snippet: As the prognosis grows more bleak, a study finds, family members begin to misinterpret what doctors are trying to tell them.

docs.lead_paragraph: The cuts, which have left many low-income women with inconvenient or costly options for treatment, grew out of a plan to eliminate state support for Planned Parenthood.

headline.seo: Texas Women’s Clinics Retreat as Finances Are Cut
headline.main: Women in Texas Losing Options for Health Care in Abortion Fight
headline.print_headline: Women in Texas Losing Options For Health Care

docs.abstract: Republican-controlled Legislature in Texas has cut financing for women's health by two-thirds, leaving many low-income women with inconvenient or costly options for treatment; law, intended to eliminate state support for Planned Parenthood, also forces other clinics not affiliated with the agency to close; supporters say cutbacks were motivated by the fight against abortion but none of the clinics, even the ones run by Planned Parenthood, performed abortions.
docs.snippet: The cuts, which have left many low-income women with inconvenient or costly options for treatment, grew out of a plan to eliminate state support for Planned Parenthood.
